comment.author: 64838194@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/kakul]  For "common" women, it was just an extension of the utilitarian apron. For fashionable women, it was often called the "Polonaise" style, which usually had side and/or back attachments, leading to a bustle, since these were all popular at the same time (mid-1880's). 
The "Princess" style was popular in the 1880's but without such a defined bustle. 
Sometimes, the apron was split into two parts and either left to hang down the front of the skirt or gathered up to the hip to meet the fabric in back.
